data.text: Is a Bike Fit Worth It?

Hello, Curious how many of you have gotten a bike fit and if you thought it was worth it. I'm looking to get on done in the future, but don't have the funds atm. Really, I feel pretty comfortable except for the saddle just destroying my ass. I think it's too narrow. Any thoughts? Do you think but fits are necessary for touring/leisure biking? I just spent a ton on the biking set up and equipment.
100% the best money you'll spend
data.author: Craig Bunyan

data.text: Any comfort issues you have on a short ride will be really an issue on a longer touring ride. Deffinitely a good idea to have a bike fit if full days in the saddle are a goal.
data.author: Lee Veinotte

data.text: Most people can do a perfectly decent bike fit with a little knowledge. If your body isn't twisted from an accident or one leg is much longer than the other. Watch a few bike fit video and tweek your possition if you think it may help. It's a time / money thing Some helpful info from a pro race team physio. üëá I'm not saying bike fits arnt worth it, just try it yourself first especially if your looking to save money
data.author: Duncan Pringle

data.text: I did that...watched a ton of videos...thought I have it quite dialed in...at the end I went ti bike fitter (only as precaution because back injury) and we changed the position quite a bit. Doing it yourself can be so inaccurate I would always opt to pay a pro do it if funds alowed.
data.author: Rok Pajer

data.text:
https://www.google.com/search?q=bike+fit+katie+kookaburra&client=ms-android-xiaomi-rvo3&biw=393&bih=732&tbm=vid&sxsrf=ALiCzsafrWA-AfYKFp21-SECj99J6iNz2Q%3A1652285489273&ei=MeB7YuSeEKS68gKM37iQCQ&oq=bike+fit+katie&gs_lcp=ChBtb2JpbGUtZ3dzLXZpZGVvEAEYAjIFCCEQoAEyBQghEKABMggIIRAWEB0QHjoHCAAQsQMQQzoFCAAQgAQ6BAgAEEM6BggAEAcQHjoKCAAQgAQQhwIQFDoFCAAQkQI6BggAEBYQHjoICAAQFhAKEB46BwghEAoQoAE6BAghEBVQmx5Y_StgjzloAHAAeACAAXeIAcoFkgEDMi41mAEAoAEBqgEQbW9iaWxlLWd3cy12aWRlb8ABAQ&sclient=mobile-gws-video#fpstate=ive&vld=cid:2fb899c2,vid:GbXOSZJ1I3w,st:0

data.author: Duncan Pringle

data.text: There's a lot of extra info in that Google search. Haha
data.author: Brian DiCapo

data.text: Saddle comfort changes with more hours in the saddle and changes to riding technique ‚Äî especially learning to use your weight more to ‚Äúfloat‚Äù on the pedals and direct that weight into forward motion. Softer wider seats can actually begin to cut off circulation ‚Äî as the uncompressed sections pillow up basically. So you want something that has some firmness and correct width to firmly support your sit bones. But enough flexibility so that you don‚Äôt put TOO much pressure on.
data.author: Joe Jeffery

data.text: I went as precaution as I have some back problems. I did not expect a lot to change but it did. Position is waaay more confortable now and even feel more efficient. Anyone who cycles regularly will benefit from bike fit.
data.author: Rok Pajer

data.text: Money well spent, yes. And I'm cheapo cheap.
data.author: Pierre Moreels

data.text: I waited 2 years before getting my first fit. I had knee issues on big rides because my fit was way off. If you're only doing short rides you will probably be ok, but you will have less pain issues if you invest in a fit from the beginning.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: so after getting the fit, did your pain go away?
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: completely.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: A bike fitter will put you're knee at between a 28-32 degree angle when the pedal is pointed towards the ground and move the seat such that a weight hanging from a string below your knee cap is directly over the center of the pedal when the pedal is parallel to the flow pointed forward. Ideally your arms would be around 90 from your body when holding onto the handlebars. For a road bike I like the handlebars to be about 1 fist below the seat but that's personal preference. Bike shops should let you try a saddle for 2 weeks with a return policy. Its a little expensive but Specialized has recently come out with a 3-d printed saddle called the Power Pro with Mirror - I just picked on up and it seems pretty amazing.
data.author: Tom Hill

data.text: Cleat position can effect knee pain. You can stand up and bend both knees and see if they turn in our out and adjust your foot position so that the knee bends strait and put the cleats in that same position
data.author: Tom Hill

data.text: I'm gonna check that out. Might go for a bike fit first.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text:
I set up my own bikes and this is my simple and relatively quick process: I set saddle height and fore/aft positioning first. For height, I use the simple method of riding/coasting with my heel on the pedal and adjusting the saddle for full leg extension a the bottom of the stroke. When you ride with proper foot positioning, this will give you a slight bend in the knee. For fore/aft position, I run a plumb line from my knee down through the pedal spindle of the forward pedal when cranks are parallel to the ground. I use a lead fishing weight on a string. You can do this alone, but a second person helps. Lots of web pages and videos on this. Lastly, I set my bar position using Lee McCormick's RAD approach which you can see here (this is the less complex of his approach and leaves you with a helpful tool for setting up any bike's RAD). I cannot stress enough how helpful the RAD setup is (though it doesn't touch on saddle position): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rHagRovHSYs
HOW TO FIT A MOUNTAIN BIKE TO YOUR BODY | Free Fit Kit
youtube.com
data.author: Wade Patterson

data.text: I'll check this out
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I've seen some very poor bike fits. Unless you are going to go down a qualified physiotherapist fit route. Save your money and watch u tube
data.author: Mark Jackson

data.text: this is what I'm afraid of. Paying $300 bucks and still having the same problems
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I've done a few bike fits, for keen cyclists suffering persistent issues and pain. I'm a soft tissue therapist. (A mix of massage, osteopathy and physiotherapy) My best advice is to start with what's comfortable, accept that spending hours riding is going to take adaptation. Do not be afraid to change seat height, bar height or reach. You'll adapt and learn. üëçüëç .
data.author: Mark Jackson

data.text: Well worth it.
data.author: Scott Hood

data.text: If you have pain and discomfort and want to put in big days in the saddle then yes.
data.author: Patrick Taylor

data.text: Built up enough bikes over the years I can comfortably do my own fit. However if I was new to riding again I would have gone the bike fitting route; I learned a lot through trial and error.
data.author: Derek Poshtar

data.text: I had two bike fits. One was terrible and I switched everything back within a week. The other was amazing and significantly improved my riding. I also had saddle issues early on. I borrowed a few from friends until I found something reasonable. I went from not being able to ride more than 60 miles without severe pain to no longer having issues overnight.
data.author: Lonny Knabe

data.text: Based on what you said- just get a saddle fitting. Riding should be comfortable. Far too many of us look at the bike we have and just make it work. Getting a full fitting only makes it better. If you count the cost of buying different Saddles until you find the one that you like, a saddle fitting pays for itself with far less hassle.
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: A Fit stuido fitting is the Best thing I have done, Now I ride twice as much and I'm pain free, Had three bike shop fittings that was a waste of time
data.author: Larry Wilkinson

data.text: what is this? Never heard of it.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I use Tad Hughes Fit studio in Houston, takes hours but gives more data than any LBS fitting
data.author: Larry Wilkinson

data.text: I did a DYI bike fitting: corrected stem length, saddle set-back, and saddle height. Later I got a professional fitting & found I was really close. Tons of resources on line for DYI.
data.author: Mike Kehoe

data.text: yeah I just went out and tried making some adjustments, but I think my handlebars are too low? When I rode past the garage I felt like I was bent over too far forward. I also moved the saddle forward a bit, and it was more a bit more comfortable. I have a lot of pressure on my tail bone. It hurts after every ride. I think the saddle might be too narrow. I'm having a hard time getting an imprint of my sit bones. I'm pretty light. About 145-150 pounds. Tons of issues I think. I just don't want to have sore bones when I ride. That's what it feels like.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I rode with a poor fit for so long, that I got it pretty close later. I'm leery about spending $100 for someone else to tell me I had it right.
data.author: Drew Van Patter

data.text: How you sit on a saddle make a huge difference too. I have less pressure on the situation bones points with a lower handlebar, less-arched back; tilting the pelvis forward, if you will.
data.author: Mike Kehoe

data.text: A bike fit is the best investment you can do as a cyclist. You can have all the fancy stuff you want. But if you are not comfy on the bike it‚Äôs all for nothing. I got two actually, and could not be happier about having spent those money
data.author: Paolo Capozzi

data.text: Nothing speaks to fit more than saddle time. Everyone says my seat is to high...but my knees don't hurt. Perhaps I lost a watt of power...big whup I'm not racing anyone for money. Comfort not performance is key. Fit Is a starting point but one you can probably figure out on your own ad an amateur.
data.author: Bud Taylor

data.text: yeah I don't care about super efficiency. I'm doing this leisurely. I just don't want pain. I found another shop near by that does a basic fit, saddle/handlebar height. I'll probably start there. Especially the saddle. My god, my bones. I did a 17 mile ride and it hurts to sit.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Saddles can take a while to find the right one. You can get your sitbones measured for free then start looking for saddles. My hubby and I both LOVE ergon saddles
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: I'm gonna check those saddles out.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: yes...
data.author: M Guy Santiago

data.text: Waste of money, upgrade your bike and ride more instead, it‚Äôs not a mystery on how to dial it in...
data.author: Hans Moravec

data.text: Agree. 3 different bike fitters will provide 3 different fits! Most have very little muscular skeletal knowledge and went on a short training course. I've treated a few cyclists suffering directly from the bike fit they paid for.
data.author: Mark Jackson

data.text: good to know. Really all I need is a good saddle. I don't really have pain anywhere else. Just too much pressure on my back. The tailbone area hurts for a day or two after riding.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: you could also be too far back. Which places more load on your glutes and lower back and less on your quads..
data.author: Mark Jackson

data.text: I think the opposite was happening, because my sit bones were on the narrow part of the saddle towards the front. I wasn't having muscular pain in my lower back, it was the bone.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: , üëç
data.author: Mark Jackson

data.text: Make sure the points where your sit bones touch are on the proper spot on the saddle. The shape and measurement can be takin from some memory foam you sat on in the riding angle. If your saddle now is too narrow( most likely because stock saddles always are) you will know.
data.author: Steven Haught

data.text: I don't have a LBS, and did a lot of reading and did my own fit. I'm sure it's not perfect, but all of the pains I experienced while or after riding have disappeared. It makes a huge difference and is worth the money if you have a place to get it done.
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: yeah, you can definitely get 85-95% dialed in reading/watching and being intelligent. The majority of fit mistakes are major. Pro fit is often tweaking little things that you aren't able to figure out, at which point its absolutely worth it. Of course, if you have the money and a good fitter, going cutting straight to the chase is good too. Problem of is if you change bikes a lot or have a few bikes. Then it can be pretty expensive. And before anyone says if you have 4 bikes.... If you have 4 bikes you bought on Craigslist and built yourself, it's not the same as 4 $2k-5k bikes. Nope.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: I need shorter cranks, and just that is going to make me adjust several things, but I‚Äôm thankful I‚Äôm able to figure it out. It is amazing how much better a bike can be.
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: yeah, most people actually do better with shorter cranks (unless your bike came with unreasonably short cranks). I actually feel like my road bike is supremely dialed in. My gravel/bikepacking bike is still a work in progress. A lot of that is I hate the 48cm bars for bikepacking. I just prefer a narrow bar (38cm on my road bike). Ultimately, I think I'm just going to have to live with some of its misfit.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: Yes. Definitely worth it.
data.author: Marcy Kelley

data.text: Get a fit done 100%. A few millimeters can make a huge difference.
data.author: Joe Ringer II

data.text: Saddle width is important, so is tilt. If your bars are lower than the saddle negative nose is key. Even if they are level, sometimes a degree of negative nose is nice. Me I use about 3 negative on my road bike. And 2 on my gravel. But my gravel seat is not ideal at 136mm...i need a 142-144 which is my ideal because it supports me on my sit bones. 136 is miserable even after I get "broken in" to riding. Don't worry, I just ordered a 144 after a season on the 136.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: Check out SQLabs for saddle fit. They will even send you a free kit to help measure your pelvic bone width. I used their DIY fit system and found a very comfortable saddle that I use on all my bikes.
data.author: David Lieu

data.text: Worth every cent!
data.author: Rick Adler

data.text: Whats the going rate?. One bike store in ct is charging $250
data.author: Steve Laue

data.text: here in CT I've seen a basic one for $100, and an extensive one for $300. Around my area at least
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I've never gone to a fit studio but every single bike I purchased through a shop has always given me a basic bike fit. It really does help and it's worth it to at least get a basic bike fit done. Even on a leisure bike
data.author: Dan Barnes

data.text: I'm probably gonna do a basic one
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: you should at least do that. I've had one done on pretty much all my bikes and even though small tweaks make a big difference.
data.author: Dan Barnes

data.text: They like to pretend bike fitting is science. But it's art. Subject to interpretation.
data.author: Barkley Phan

data.text: Got fitted for two bikes in one session. $450, the most money I've ever wasted.
data.author: Glen Carter

data.text: wasted. Is that the key word?
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Yup, the only thing I got out of the sessions was that I had to rely upon myself to get fitted. I started writing down every measurement before and after changes, and by golly-gee-crumpet, am fairly comfortable on the bike now. The settings post-fit about killed me, and I did try them for a few weeks. Way wasted money.
data.author: Glen Carter

data.text: interesting ü§î. Glad you found your fit now. I have to tinker with mine more.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I think as well as fit core strenth is important, it can make a big difference to comfort. I think you can get a decent fit by tinkering yourself.
data.author: Alistair Tor
